data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Aim of the Policy is to provide information with regards to how the service will operate. The document will describe the services provided by the Clinical Site Team, and key working relationships within MSE.
Scope

MSE NHS Trust have patient safety as a Key priority and will be maintained at all times. The Clinical Site team is dedicated to promoting a positive safety culture throughout the trust. The Clinical Site team will ensure that patients are admitted in a timely manner to the most appropriate clinical area, leading to the reduction in patient transfers between wards.
The clinical site management team provides senior nursing support, professional leadership and advice to all clinical areas within the trust 24 hours a day 7 days a week.
Key Objectives:
To support the maintenance of patient flow;
To be the single point of access between wards, clinical areas and departments across the whole organisation;
To escalate any major concerns to senior managers in the out of hours period in a timely manner;
To maintain the safety of the trust;
To liaise with both internal and external agencies;

To maintain availability of a specialist bed in each area for Stroke, Gynaecology, ENT, Cardiology, Oncology, Plastics and Vascular for emergency admissions, paediatrics and maternity delivery beds as per specific site. To inform and liaise with the Teletracking Control Centre to ensure appropriate allocations and bed utilisation across all wards. This includes Repats, urgent and clinic admissions.
Daily Operational Meetings
Daily Operational meetings will take place at 08:45, 12:00, 15:00, 17:00 and with on call teams at 19:00.
All staff must understand the importance of utilising and maintaining Teletracking accuracy to support patient flow.
The Clinical Site Co-ordinator on duty will provide an over view of the site activity and will inform all relevant staff of any changes to the daily operational meetings/times/venue.

The Clinical Site Co-ordinator will facilitate efficient and effective flow throughout the trust, within MSE Trust. Whilst balancing both the elective and emergency demand, as well as accommodating repatriation of planned and urgent patients from external agencies and Hospitals.
(Refer to Appendix 3 for Repatriation from Other Hospitals, and Appendix 4 Medically Expected Emergency Admissions).

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Clinical Site Team are responsible for ensuring that the hospital is able to accommodate:
Emergency admissions;
Elective admissions;
Essential transfers into and out of MSE;
The Safe outlying of medically stable patients due to capacity issues.
The Trust operates a Site Management policy which states that;
The Clinical Site Co-ordinator has the delegated authority for implementation of the policy;
Patients should only be placed in an area that is adequately staff with nursing /midwifery and medical cover, and has the necessary clinical equipment to manage the presenting condition;
Patients will be placed in same sex bay areas, except for HDU / ITU. The exception is only during Opel 3 status and with the guidance of the Director on call;
Following the first assessment and initial move, patients should only be moved subsequently due to clinical needs;
Full compliance will be maintained with Infection Prevention Policies;
All incidents of non-compliance to the bed policy should be recorded on a Trust Incident Form (Datix);

The Site Management policy will be used in conjunction with other operational policies that are likely to impact upon capacity utilisation i.e. Winter Planning / Major Incidents/ MSE Full Capacity Protocol;
Patients should not be moved from ward areas after 23.00 and before 06.00 unless clinically indicated.
Work flows
The Site Management function is the lead for all inpatient movements into, within and out of the hospital.
It is the central escalation contact point for all support functions attached to inpatients.
The team are the escalation liaison point for issues relating to delays in patient discharges.
The team are the central focus for disseminating key information relating to changes in service i.e. ward closures due to infection.

The Trust aims to ensure that patients receive care in the right place at the right time. The failure to declare Pending and Confirmed discharges via Teletracking in a timely manner impacts negatively upon patient care and experience. Clinical areas must update their Teletracking information immediately once it is known that a decision to discharge or transfer a patient is made.
Patient Transfer Guidelines

Ideally all patients should receive their on-going treatment in the appropriate specialist ward. However occasionally, due to the pressure of admissions in a particular speciality, it may be necessary to admit or transfer patients to an outlying ward within another speciality.
The following patients are the most suitable to be transferred:
A patient with an established plan of care, who can be safely managed in a non-specialised area;
A patient who has a clear discharge plan;
By exception and during Opel 3 or 4 status, patients may be identified for outlying directly from an Emergency Pathway.

In circumstances where there are no patients who meet the above criteria, medical and nursing / midwifery teams are responsible for the patient, and must identify the most medically stable patient for transfer. This must be documented in the patient's notes by either the Registrar or Consultant.
(Refer to Appendix A for Management of outlying patients within MSE and also refer to the Adult patient transfer policy; register number 11042).

Security Requirements
Data security
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's IT Policies;
Data sharing agreements will be drawn up to cover all data sharing outside the Trust in accordance with the Trust MSBPO-18003 Overarching Information Sharing Protocol;
Hospital information/patient data will only be downloaded onto devices provided by the Trust which are encrypted;
Databases will be registered on the Trust database of databases;
A data mapping form will be completed for all routine data flows leaving the Trust;
Patient identifiable information will only be sent out of the Trust from an nhs.net account or other secure route (never from an nhs.uk account).
Security for Patients

This service is not directly accessed by patients. In the event that a patient should directly access the service it will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Security Policy.
Security for Staff
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Lone Worker; Risk Management Policies and Security Policy.
Medical Records Security
Medical records are not routinely managed by this service. In the event that medical records are handled they will be managed confidentially at all times and stored securely in locked office.
All movement of patient records will be accurately tracked in accordance with the Trust's Case note Tracking Policy.
All new documentation will be secured into the folder prior to it leaving the department.

Staffing
Staffing Profile

Clinical Site Co-ordinators are based on site and rotate across MSE once familiarisation and full training has been provided, 2 x band 7 on site, and a teletracking Control Centre supervisor- Band 8a who has overview of all 3 sites and supports where necessary.
Training requirements
All staff within the Site Management Team will comply with the Trust Mandatory Training Programme, and NHSLA requirements.
In addition the Clinical Staff will maintain their own requirements for continuous professional development.
Registered Nurses: Will be able to demonstrate continuous professional development in line with NMC requirements for revalidation.
All staff will be required to undertake Silver Operations training/major incident training.
All Staff Will be required to undertake ILS Training.
Contingency

The contingency plans for increased capacity differ from each site and would be discussed in each bed meeting/ if this Is needed. If out of hours this would go through the SMOC or EXEC on call via the SMOC.
Any increase in capacity needs to be approved either by the Chief Operating Officer in hours and the Director On call out of hours.
Breaches of this operational policy
In the event of any of the procedures outlined in this policy not being adhered to, that leads to patient harm, then a Datix must be completed.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Clinical Governance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local teletracking bed management guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Clinical Governance Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Band 8a supervisor within the Teletracking Control Centre is responsible for the clinical staff working in the Department. The on-site Teletracking Clinical Site Co- ordinator is accountable for their practice under their Professional Code of Conduct, working within their competencies and scope of practice as identified in their job description.
Financial accountability lies with the Teletracking Control Centre Lead.

Appendix 1: Management of outlying patients

The Clinical Site Team in partnership with the Teletracking Control Centre will consider the patient dependency and staffing levels & skills on each outlying ward and in conjunction with the Nurse in Charge ensure that patients are placed into an appropriate available bed.
Current outlying wards
Outlying wards differ per site. This will be discussed on a case by case basis and discussed at the bed meetings to ensure all departments are aware of the plan.
Plans also to be put in place that these patients are reviewed by the correct Doctors and they are also aware of the outliers.
Other
All patients who require Tracheostomy care can only be placed on HDU or wards where there is a trained trachy nurse to look after the patient – this differs per site.
All patients who require NIV (Non-invasive ventilation) can only be placed the wards that are identified on each site with the correct trained nurses.
Approval Process
At all bed meetings all nursing leads are asked if there are any concerns with outliers and have all outliers have been reviewed on a daily basis.
All Medical outliers are approved as being fit to outlie to a Medical Ward by the Site team with either a medical registrar or consultant. This should also be documented within patient's case notes.

All patients who cannot be placed on their correct ward for their condition must be approved as “fit to outlie” to an alternative ward by the clinical site team with either a Registrar or Consultant. This should also be documented within patient's case notes.
Ward Buddy System with Medical Teams
Patients who need to be outliers should first be considered for placement on their buddy ward because the medical teams will most accurately fit with their condition:
Corresponding teams to do a daily ward round on the medical outlier wards.
It is expected that Physician of the Day (POD) should do post take round in the outlier wards then handover patients to the corresponding designated team.
Only stable patients can be moved to outlier wards from AMU and no direct admissions from A&E to these wards without a senior medical review (Registrar and above).
